projects.project_title: CE25-149 - Enhancing Project DHARMA; evaluating a community-based drug checking navigator intervention to prevent overdoses
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
Fentanyl and xylazine pose new life-threatening risks to people who use drugs (PWUD), particularly in rural
areas such as in northern New England. Community-based drug checking services may be an impactful
approach to informing PWUD about their drug supply, leading to an increase in safer drug use decision-making
and behaviors, and ultimately reducing overdose; but such a strategy has yet to be evaluated. We propose a
difference-in-differences study to develop, implement, and evaluate the impact of an enhanced drug checking
navigator (DCN) intervention on overdose prevention. The study, implemented by community-based syringe
service programs, will compare differences in overdose prevalence in Maine, where the DCN intervention will
be implemented, to New Hampshire, where the intervention will not be implemented.

projects.project_title: Exploring morphological changes in supporting cell: new cell polarity perspective and approaches
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT
Auditory function relies not only on sensory cells and second-order neurons but also on glial cells known as
supporting cells, which provide a rigid yet flexible structural scaffold crucial for amplifying low-intensity sounds,
for example. Supporting cells are highly specialized and their morphogenesis remains incompletely understood
due to extensive remodeling during cell maturation and the challenge of isolating individual cell behavior within
an intricate, repetitive organ architecture. This project introduces a novel conceptual approach and new tools to
track changes in supporting cell morphology during auditory organ development and throughout life.

projects.project_title: Nat. PETE HAZMAT Training Initiative at DOE Nuclear Weapons Complex
projects.project_description:
Narrative
 The Department of Energy and predecessor agencies have been involved in the
research, production and testing of nuclear weapons since the 1940s. During that time,
numerous facilities, both government and privately-owned, were constructed or leased
across the country to support the effort, generating large quantities of radioactive and
hazardous materials that resulted in the contamination of many of the facilities and
surrounding areas.
 In 1994, to protect the staff and workers doing DOE cleanup and waste
management work, legislation was enacted to allow the Department of Energy to fund
NIEHS to develop Worker Training programs that would assure workers, other facility
personnel, and community responders the knowledge and skills to protect themselves
and their communities from hazardous conditions in the workplace.
 The Community College Consortium for Health and Safety Training (CCCHST)
has been continuously supported by NIEHS since 1995 to provide quality training that is
efficient, consistent, flexible, and cost-effective for the multiple tiers of contractors at
DOE sites including the Oakridge complex, Portsmouth, Pantex, the Savannah River
Site, and Los Alamos National Lab and in 2026 CCCHST will provide 3,500 students
with 350 courses for a total 35,000 contact hours of training, with an average 75 courses
delivered online.

projects.project_title: Tissue-specific roles for muscle-matrix adhesion in neuromuscular development and homeostasis
projects.project_description:
Dystroglycanopathies are clinically heterogeneous, multisystem disorders that can lead to severe progressive
neuromuscular degeneration, which deleteriously impacts quality of life and is frequently lethal. There are no
cures. We aim to use the advantages of the zebrafish model to shed light on how different tissues impact
neuromuscular degeneration and how embryonic development affects disease progression.

projects.project_title: Impact of Age-Related Clonal Hematopoiesis on Alzheimer's Disease
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Alzheimer's disease (AD) has a devastating effect on patients, caregivers, and society, and effective therapeutic
interventions are urgently needed to prevent and cure dementia. An age-related blood phenomenon called clonal
hematopoiesis (CH) was recently identified as a potential protective factor for AD in a population study; however,
validation and mechanistic studies are not possible in humans. Our project will model CH and AD in mice to
uncover mechanistic links between peripheral blood and brain dysfunction and nominate new resilience and
protective targets for AD.

projects.project_title: Gastric Endocrine Functions in Skeletal Homeostasis
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
Bariatric surgery leads to durable weight loss, enhances quality of life and improves metabolic health; however,
bone loss is a side effect. This project uses innovative genetic mouse models to define novel molecular
signaling pathways between the gut and the bone that impact skeletal health, targeting endocrine cells in the
stomach. This work will define novel functions of gastric endocrine cells and broadly apply to metabolic bone
disorders and osteoporosis.

projects.project_title: Environmental Influences on Child Health Outcomes in Maine (ECHO-ME)
projects.project_description: With the highest proportion of the population living in rural areas of any state, Maine’s pediatric population would benefit from access to high-quality, multisite clinical trials that improve health outcomes across five key areas: obesity, pre-, peri-, and postnatal health; neurodevelopmental outcomes; positive health; and lower airway disease. As a new partner in the ECHO IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network, our proposed program, Environmental Influences on Child Health Outcomes in Maine (ECHO-ME), would build capacity among pediatric investigators at all levels to lead and participate in multi-center clinical trials, in partnership with rural communities, to improve pediatric health outcomes for children in Maine and across the country.

projects.project_title: Immuno-cardiology 2025 Symposium
projects.project_description: This proposal seeks support for Immuno-Cardiology 2025, a research symposium that will highlight new discoveries in the growing field of immuno-cardiology and explore therapeutic approaches that limit cardiac inflammation and associated fibrosis. The meeting is unique in that it will bring together academic, clinical and pharmaceutical-based scientists, will include researchers looking at relevant organ systems other than the heart, and will showcase the work of young investigators. NIH support for the symposium will specifically provide travel funding to promote participation by early career scientists, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

projects.project_title: New Mechanisms of Mitochondrial Toxicity: Focus on Antibacterial Agent Cetylpyridinium Chloride Effects on Immune and Barrier Cells
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
CPC is increasingly found at high doses in hygiene, cleaning, pharmaceutical, and food products and is a
triclosan replacement but is several-fold more mitotoxic than it and other banned mitochondrial toxicants.
We have discovered that CPC is a potent mitochondrial toxicant, and the proposed research will employ
molecular, biochemical, and biophysical tools, including organismal studies in C. elegans and super-resolution
fluorescence microscopy, to unravel the mechanisms by which CPC harms mitochondria. This research will
fulfill an urgent need by providing insights into CPC effects on environmental human health and will define new
general modes of mitotoxicity for consideration in toxicity testing workflows.

projects.project_title: Developing a Multi-Organ Multi-Omics Computational Framework for StudyingMammalian Iron Systems Biology
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Iron deficiency-related anemia affects >1.2 billion individuals worldwide, and iron deficiency without anemia is
even more frequent. Our laboratory aims will investigate the etiology of iron disorders by developing a new
computational approach that allows the integrative study of iron metabolism across multiple tissues
simultaneously. We believe this approach will be crucial in facilitating personalized medicine tailored to each
patient’s specific needs.

projects.project_title: The Genetics of the Neuromuscular Junction: Mechanisms and Disease Models
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE (Parent Application)
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease affects approximately 1:2500 people and the largest family of genes associated
with this disorder is the tRNA-synthetases. How mutations in these ubiquitous genes lead to the degeneration
of specific nerves is unknown. We are exploring the biochemical and cell biological basis of these disorders
using mice and human cell lines engineered to model patient mutations; this work will also test both
pharmacological and gene therapy treatment strategies.

projects.project_title: NPETE's  Community College Consortium for Health & Safety
projects.project_description:
The goal of CCCHST is to make NIEHS-approved worker training nationally available through
over 100 CCCHST organizations, whose instructors are prepared through a Train-the-Trainer
model program, offering hazardous materials instruction in nearly all states of the
nation. CCCHST instructors, prepared and supported by PETE, will annually train a minimum
40,000 students, workers, and supervisors to protect themselves and their communities from
exposure to hazardous materials encountered during hazardous waste site cleanup, Brownfields
redevelopment, transportation of hazardous materials, and response to spills and releases of
hazardous materials, offering a minimum 300,000 contact hours of instruction each year.
 Each year, PETE and Eastern Iowa Community Colleges (EICC), or another qualified
CCCHST institution, will provide an intensive 5.5-day, hands-on Great Environmental Safety
Trainers (GreatEST) Train-the-Trainer Institute for up to 20 instructors entering membership
in CCCHST, supplemented with Internet-supported instructor training and a virtual waste site;
an optional 2.5-day face-to-face Industrial Emergency Spill Response Train-the-Trainer; annual
StayFresher training via Zoom for all members, and a 2.5 day annual Conference for 50
CCCHST members.
 PETE and Barton Community College, KS, will also provide direct worker training for a
minimum 600 Total Military Family personnel at three Midwest bases annually, Fort Riley (KS),
Fort Sill (OK), Fort Carson (CO), and via Zoom nationally and internationally for Veterans,
soon-to-retire military personnel or family members who need OSHA certifications to enhance
employment opportunities.

projects.project_title: Improving Rural Neonatal Birth Outcomes through Neonatal Resuscitation Simulation Training
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
Newborns delivered in rural hospitals with low birth rates experience significant disparities including rates of
death and brain injury when adverse birthing events necessitate immediate resuscitation because rural delivery
teams lack opportunities to practice, leading to poor adherence with Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP)
guidelines. Simulation training is an evidence based strategy for rural teams to deliberately practice neonatal
resuscitation, a high acuity, low frequency occurrence. We will develop and compare the efficacy of a novel,
inexpensive hologram-based (HoloBabyTM) telesimulation technology with high-fidelity telesimulation using a
randomized non-inferiority cluster trial, assessing NRP adherence, teamwork and communication skills to
enable rural delivery room teams to maintain NRP skills and decrease rural neonatal health disparities.

projects.project_title: Emerging Leaders in Regenerative Biology and Development (ReBilD)
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The field of regenerative medicine, i.e., the development of new approaches to promote restoration or
replacement of damaged tissues, organs, or entire body parts in humans, has great potential for treatment of
age-related and injury-induced tissue or organ damage. However, while the field of regeneration biology has
grown dramatically in recent decades, there has not been corresponding growth in a workforce with the skills
and knowledge to perform research in this field. We will meet this need by creating and implementing a program,
“Emerging leaders in Regenerative Biology and Development (ReBilD) Program,” at the MDI Biological
Laboratory that will include training and mentoring of participants in hands-on research using animal species that
differ in regeneration capacity; a visiting scientist program for advanced technical training; and an online
networking forum for long-term, post-Program interactions among Program participants and other researchers
in the field, and for sustained growth of this research community.

projects.project_title: Community Partnerships in Disaster Site  Training
projects.project_description:
The Partnership for Environmental Technology Education (PETE) will offer 40-hour
Disaster Site Response Training (DSRT) for Instructors held at the National Preparedness
Institute, Indian River State College, FL, to annually train up to 20 Haz Mat disaster response
instructors serving the nation’s community colleges, alternative high schools, community-based
and faith-based response groups, military, and the nation’s first responders.
 Training partners include OAI’s BPSOS and Mendez Environmental protecting the Gulf
and OAI’s ABS Training and Consulting in the Midwest; CERT High School/AmeriCorps based
in Wisconsin; PathStone Corporation in Puerto Rico and Ohio preparing farmworkers,
Brownfields students and community members; Tribal Colleges led by Saginaw Chippewa
College in Michigan; and Pacific Rim Colleges led by Guam Community College.
 Following instructor training, consortium members will annually train a minimum 1,495
community college students, alternative/technical high school students, first responders and
community volunteers to respond to local Haz Mat disasters, offering 100 courses and over
11,845 contact hours of local training annually.

projects.project_title: NPETE'S Community College Consortium for Health & Safety
projects.project_description:
The goal of the Community College Consortium for Health and Safety Training
(CCCHST), sponsored by the National Partnership for Environmental Technology Education
(NPETE), is to help the nation be better prepared to prevent and respond to hazardous materials
incidents through the training of instructors serving workers from business and industry;
students from community and tribal colleges. technical schools, and alternative schools; first
responders; transitioning military; and members of community-based and faith-based
organizations in targeted communities. CCCHST will make NIEHS-approved training
nationally available through over 150 CCCHST members, prepared through a Train-the-Trainer
model program, to offer hazardous materials and disaster preparedness instruction in nearly all
states of the nation and its territories. Over 150,000 workers, students, and citizens, prepared by
CCCHST instructors over a five-year period, will understand how to protect themselves and
their communities when working with hazardous chemicals and hazardous situations.

projects.project_title: Enabling High-Dimensional Flow Cytometry and Extracellular Particle Analysis at MaineHealth Institute for Research
projects.project_description:
This research is crucial to public health as it enhances our understanding of complex cellular mechanisms
and disease processes, leading to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. By expanding and
elevating flow cytometry capabilities at MHIR, more detailed and precise analysis of cell populations is
achievable, facilitating advanced research in immune responses, metabolic disorders, and many health
conditions. The broader community ultimately benefits from scientific innovation, education of future
scientists and doctors, and regional institutional collaborations through discoveries that contribute to
improved healthcare.

projects.project_title: Defining the Roles of Bone Marrow Adipocytes and FABP4/5 Signaling in Multiple Myeloma Drug Resistance
projects.project_description:
NARRATIVE
The overall goal of this application is to change how multiple myeloma, an incurable blood cancer, is understood
and treated. We will discover new forms of cancer drug resistance that are driven by fat cell-derived factors.
Thus, we will expose new interventions to overcome drug resistance to improve survival and quality of life for
myeloma patients and patients with other cancers that grow in the bone.

projects.project_title: Project MultiNav: A gamified multisensory training and navigation system for blind and visually impaired people
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project aims to solve the decades‐long blind and visually impaired (BVI) navigaƟon problem by disrupƟng the all‐too‐
common tendency to develop for isolated trip segments, segregated navigaƟon tasks, and singular sensory modaliƟes
(most oŌen through natural language) that has perpetuated the assisƟve technology status quo. To do so, we study and
implement MulƟNav, a novel mulƟsensory soluƟon that combines pre‐journey map learning with in‐situ navigaƟon
assistance, wrapped in a learnable and usable smartphone applicaƟon with strong pathways to translaƟon. Our user‐driven
inclusive design approach is expected to solve high‐probability navigaƟon challenges with tractable and measurable
outcomes that will improve BVI mobility, independence, and overall quality of life as a sustainable plaƞorm with
widespread adopƟon.

projects.project_title: MaineHealth Cancer Care Network (MHCCN) and NCORP Activities across the Lifespan
projects.project_description: The State of Maine faces access to cancer care challenges, as it is the most rural and oldest state in the nation. Historically, cancer patients and their families in Maine have had inconsistent access to state-of-the-art federally-sponsored cancer research trials. The MaineHealth Cancer Care Network (MHCCN) Lifespan proposal provides a wonderful opportunity and departure point for our organization to be considered for inclusion in the NCI Community Oncology Program and to provide access for our patients to this vital resource. We value making substantive contributions and providing leadership to NCORP over the next award period.

projects.project_title: The Jackson Laboratory Senescence Tissue Mapping Center (JAX-Sen TMC)
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Senescence refers to the loss of cell function with aging and is associated with many chronic diseases of
aging, but the mechanisms by which this happens is poorly understood at a molecular level. The proposed
project seeks to advance knowledge of the molecular features of senescence through cutting-edge profiling
techniques and mouse resources that will complement efforts at the human level to map senescence in human
cells and tissues.

projects.project_title: The Jackson Laboratory Senescence Tissue Mapping Center (JAX-Sen TMC) - Admin Core
A Novel Wild-derived Diversity Mouse Population for Precision Mapping and Systems Genetics
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Despite their prominence in biomedical research, most studies that use inbred mice to model human diseases
ultimately fail to improve treatment outcomes for human patients. This failure likely owes, at least in part, to the
fact that inbred laboratory mice do not reflect the genetic diversity of human populations, and therefore stop short
of accurately modelling individual heterogeneity in disease etiology and treatment response. To overcome these
limitations of inbred laboratory mice, this project will generate a new, genetically diverse mouse population that
mirrors the genetic complexity of human populations and that will serve as a powerful live-animal resource for
numerous areas of biomedical research, including toxicology, preclinical drug testing, gene mapping, and
systems genetics.

projects.project_title: The Role of Irisin in Initiating Resorption During the Skeletal Response to Exercise
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Exercise and physical loading support bone health, and better understanding the cellular mechanisms involved
will help to treat an aging population facing degenerative bone diseases. This project studies the signaling
pathways by which irisin, a signaling factor released from muscle during exercise, affects key cells within bone
to guide adaptation of the tissue. By delineating these mechanisms, our work will contribute to the
understanding of skeletal adaption and inform future efforts at developing therapeutics to protect bone health.

projects.project_title: Short Course on Methods for MultiOmics Data Analysis
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Our Short Course on Methods for MultiOmics Data Analysis will increase knowledge of genomic data science,
elevate the scientific and translational value of Common Fund data, and grow the community of Common Fund
data users with an emphasis on women and underrepresented minorities. We will accomplish this through an
intensive immersion experience in an environment that brings together participants and faculty with diverse
backgrounds who share an interest in applying genomic data science in their work.

projects.project_title: Discovery of host genetic elements affecting response to immune checkpoint inhibitors
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Despite the remarkable clinical success of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) in treating previously refractory
cancers, the majority of patients still do not have meaningful responses, likely due to tumor-intrinsic and to host-
specific factors such as the genetic make-up of the patient. We have developed powerful genetic platforms based
on advanced genetically diverse mouse models, computational algorithms, and patient-derived micro-
organosphere (MOS) technology to map genes in both mice and humans that modify host response to an ICI.
Our enhanced understanding of host genetic mechanisms governing ICI response will be important to devising
predictive biomarkers and, importantly, novel therapeutics to enhance ICI effectiveness; thus, we now propose
to expand on our recent discoveries to precisely define the genetic network controlling host response to ICIs,
and to test emerging ICI and ICI combinations in our integrated genetic diversity/MOS system.

projects.project_title: The Role of Aco2 in progressive hearing loss
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Deafness is a major health issue affecting millions of people worldwide, and genetic mutations in mitochondrial-
related genes are a significant contributing factor. The research proposed aims to characterize the role of ACO2,
a mitochondrial enzyme in the energy metabolism pathway that was associated with syndromic hearing loss in
infants and children. A new and first Aco2 mouse model will allow us to characterize the progression of
mitochondrial dysfunction, neuronal degeneration, and deafness and to test possible therapeutic interventions.

projects.project_title: Vascular Contributions to Cognitive Impairment and Dementia (VCID)
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The field of vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) has surged in interest in recent
years with the acceptance that vascular dysfunction may be central to cognitive aging and in many cases of
Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias. However, there is a current need for a workshop to facilitate
networking and collaboration within the interdisciplinary VCID field, to provide participants access to the latest
advances in this area, and to provide opportunities to focus resources to rapidly translate scientific discoveries
into prevention, treatment, and cure. Thus, the purpose of the proposed Jackson Laboratory (JAX) VCID
workshop is to provide a setting for participants to learn about the history of VCID, the current state of our
understanding, the recent advances and the areas emerging as key for future studies, and to develop the next,
increasingly diverse, generation of basic and clinical neuroscientists.

projects.project_title: Identifying tissue-specific interactions to bridge mechanisms underlying muscle degeneration in Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation and Dystroglycanopathies
projects.project_description:
Both Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation and dystroglycanopathies are clinically heterogenous, multisystem
disorders that can lead to severe progressive neural and muscular degeneration, which deleteriously impacts
quality of life and is frequently lethal. There are currently no cures for these diseases. We aim to leverage a
zebrafish model to gain insight into tissue-specific impacts of dpm3 expression on neuromuscular development
and provide foundational knowledge on mechanisms of disease progression in vivo.

projects.project_title: IND-enabling safety and toxicity testing of a subcutaneous formulation of the PTP1B inhibitor MSI-1436, a novel strategy for treating fatal cardiomyopathy in Duchenne muscular dystrophy patients
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Most patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), a devastating inherited muscle wasting
disease, die from heart failure in their second or third decade of life. We have identified a novel,
subcutaneously administered drug candidate that slows the progressive damage to the heart associated with
DMD. Our proposed studies will carry out safety and toxicology testing of this drug candidate, which is the final
requirement before clinical trials in humans can begin.

projects.project_title: VCID CWOW: Identifying Novel Targets to Treat Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy
projects.project_description: Although declining health of blood vessels in the brain is now thought to contribute to many cases of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias, there are no treatments that target blood vessel health. Here, we will use gene and protein profiling from brain samples of human AD patients and mouse models to identify putative therapeutic targets. Data will be integrated and analyzed to prioritize candidate genes and proteins that will be tested for their ability to reduce damage to blood vessels in the brain using mouse models.

projects.project_title: SKYSCAN 1276 CMOS in vivo microCT
projects.project_description:
High resolution imaging is a corner stone of pre-clinical research. We request funds to purchase a high
resolution microcomputed tomograph with high scan speeds and high resolution to support a total of 19 major
and minor NIH supported users for their bone and vascular disease research.

projects.project_title: Customizable 3D Matrix to Investigate Glycan Function
projects.project_description:
Customizable 3D Matrix to Investigate Glycan Function
Pi: Matthew Brichacek; Co-I: William Gramlich, University of Maine
Project Narrative
The proposed research will create a diagnostic material system to identify and quantify interactions between
glycans and protein. New synthetic techniques will be developed to create thiol-functionalized glycans that
probe fundamental biomacromolecule interactions with precise spatiotemporal control of glycan type and
activity. Incorporation of these probes into novel biomaterials will benefit human health by enabling a diverse
set of scientists to identify glycans relevant to human health and explore their effects in a controlled and
customizable extracellular environment.

projects.project_title: Functional Validation of Novel Variants Associated with Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The overall goal of this proposal is to identify and validate novel genes and variants that cause congenital
diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), a common and severe birth defect that is poorly understood. We will use genomic
data from our large, well-characterized CDH patient cohort to identify novel genes and variants associated with
CDH, and prioritize these genes and variants for validation in mouse models. Using advanced genome editing
approaches, we will validate candidate variants and study promising hits in depth, providing insight into the
genetics and mechanisms that underly CDH pathology.

projects.project_title: Functional Validation of Novel Variants Associated with Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The overall goal of this proposal is to identify and validate novel genes and variants that cause congenital
diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), a common and severe birth defect that is poorly understood. We will use genomic
data from our large, well-characterized CDH patient cohort to identify novel genes and variants associated with
CDH, and prioritize these genes and variants for validation in mouse models. Using advanced genome editing
approaches, we will validate candidate variants and study promising hits in depth, providing insight into the
genetics and mechanisms that underly CDH pathology.

projects.project_title: Rapid Development of Mouse Resource Strains through the Application of Prime Editors
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 The human genome and that of its experimental surrogate, the mouse, contain an estimated 20,000 genes.
Studying these genes has traditionally involved modifying the mouse genome on a gene-by-gene and study-by-
study basis. The proposed experiments are designed to accelerate the development and decrease the cost of
mouse genome studies, moving strain development efforts from a gene-by-gene method to a more massively
parallel approach.

projects.project_title: Are you REDDE? Expanding a Mobile Vessel Safety and Training Service for Northeast Fishermen
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative:
Commercial fishermen spend one third of their lives at sea participating in one of the most
dangerous jobs in the world. REDDE Marine Safety offers its clients a “Full Service Safety
System” which includes an initial vessel audit inspection followed by periodic mobile service and
replacement on all safety equipment and specialized training for operation in northeast fisheries.
Our company’s mission is to create a culture of safety among our region’s commercial
fishermen.

projects.project_title: Rapid Development of Mouse Resource Strains through the Application of Prime Editors
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 The human genome and that of its experimental surrogate, the mouse, contain an estimated 20,000 genes.
Studying these genes has traditionally involved modifying the mouse genome on a gene-by-gene and study-by-
study basis. The proposed experiments are designed to accelerate the development and decrease the cost of
mouse genome studies, moving strain development efforts from a gene-by-gene method to a more massively
parallel approach.

projects.project_title: The Role of Phosphoinositides in Influenza Virus Assembly
projects.project_description:
The project will address the means by which influenza virus is able to hijack the host cell to
assemble new viruses from proteins and membranes produced by the cell. The project will
specifically explore the interactions between host cell membrane components, the viral matrix
protein M1, and certain conserved portions of the viral glycoprotein hemagglutinin, which is
responsible for binding of the virus to the respiratory tract and entry into host cells, but whose
frequent mutations have required vaccines to be continuously updated from season to season.
Results will be used to accelerate the search for universal anti-viral therapies which are less
susceptible to seasonal mutations of the virus.

projects.project_title: Understanding Pain Expression in Wabanaki People during Recovery: Enhancing Wabanaki Research, Data Self-Determination, and Capacity Development
Understanding Pain Expression in Wabanaki People during Recovery: Enhancing Wabanaki Research, Data Self-Determination, and Capacity Development
Zebrafish Habitat Expansion
projects.project_description:
NARRATIVE: ZEBRAFISH FACILITY EXPANSION
UMaine’s Shared Zebrafish Facility is critical for 12 faculty throughout the University of Maine. We propose to
expand UMaine’s Zebrafish Facility to accomplish the following: increase nursery space to facilitate rapid
growth of new lines, increase spawning space to increase experimental pace, and more than double the
capacity of our current system.

projects.project_title: Computational Techniques and Resources for Effective Translational Research in Alzheimer's Disease
projects.project_description: Rapidly expanding genetic and genomic datasets provide new tools for accelerating our understanding of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and enable interspecies analysis for mapping findings from model systems of AD to human molecular signatures. However, integration of multi-omic signatures to identify markers of disease remains computationally challenging. Thus, the proposed workshop on Computational Techniques and Resources for Effective Translational Research in Alzheimer’s Disease will inform and train junior investigators in state-of-the-art, rigorous computational approaches for concurrent analyses of omics data from both human studies and models of AD, with the ultimate hope of developing new genetic and genomic targets for intervention.

projects.project_title: INcreasing CLinical Trial OpportUnities anD Enrollment of Non-English Speaking Research Subjects: A Revised Research Pathway (INCLUDE)
projects.project_description:
The dramatic underrepresentation of Non-English speakers (NES) in clinical trials contributes to health
inequities and compromises the generalizability of research. Despite focus on this issue over the last decade,
including the identification of barriers to enrollment, there has been little progress toward increasing enrollment.
This study uses a modified Delphi method to reach consensus on best practice to overcome regulatory barriers
and tests the resulting process in a simulated environment using principal investigators, research staff,
interpreters and standardized patients.

projects.project_title: Ontogeny of sex differences in amygdala and hypothalamus after neonatal trauma
projects.project_description:
Although it is now clear in human neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) patients that sex differences exist in the
effects of early life pain and stress on later psychological functioning and chronic pain, the mechanisms
underlying these effects remain unclear. This project investigates the behavioral and neuroendocrine changes
that occur in a rodent NICU model of neonatal pain and stress in both male and female rats, testing the
hypothesis that there will be sex differences in the underlying mechanisms.

projects.project_title: Computational Techniques and Resources for Effective Translational Research in Alzheimer's Disease
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Rapidly expanding genetic and genomic datasets provide new tools for accelerating our understanding of
Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and enable interspecies analysis for mapping findings from model systems of AD to
human molecular signatures. However, integration of multi-omic signatures to identify markers of disease
remains computationally challenging. Thus, the proposed workshop on Computational Techniques and
Resources for Effective Translational Research in Alzheimer’s Disease will inform and train junior investigators
in state-of-the-art, rigorous computational approaches for concurrent analyses of omics data from both human
studies and models of AD, with the ultimate hope of developing new genetic and genomic targets for intervention.

projects.project_title: Mechanisms underlying sex differences in emergence of advanced osteoarthritis pain
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
Osteoarthritis (OA) pain is heterogeneous with distinct mechanisms across stages of OA pain that are poorly
understood and contributes to the variable therapeutic efficacy of treatments for OA pain. Moreover, OA pain is
more common and reported to be more severe in females compared to males. This grant explores whether
pathological changes in innervation of the OA joint and adjacent muscle determines transition between mid-
stage and advanced OA pain and whether this occurs in a sex dependent fashion that increases susceptibility
of females to develop more severe OA joint pain.

projects.project_title: Mechanisms underlying sex differences in emergence of advanced osteoarthritis pain
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
Osteoarthritis (OA) pain is heterogeneous with distinct mechanisms across stages of OA pain that are poorly
understood and contributes to the variable therapeutic efficacy of treatments for OA pain. Moreover, OA pain is
more common and reported to be more severe in females compared to males. This grant explores whether
pathological changes in innervation of the OA joint and adjacent muscle determines transition between mid-
stage and advanced OA pain and whether this occurs in a sex dependent fashion that increases susceptibility
of females to develop more severe OA joint pain.

projects.project_title: Ontogeny of sex differences in amygdala and hypothalamus after neonatal trauma
projects.project_description:
Although it is now clear in human neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) patients that sex differences exist in the
effects of early life pain and stress on later psychological functioning and chronic pain, the mechanisms
underlying these effects remain unclear. This project investigates the behavioral and neuroendocrine changes
that occur in a rodent NICU model of neonatal pain and stress in both male and female rats, testing the
hypothesis that there will be sex differences in the underlying mechanisms.

projects.project_title: Pre-Clinical Models of Infectious Diseases
Administrative Core
Comparative Genomics and Data Science Core
The MDIBL Center for Comparative Biology of Tissue Repair, Regeneration and Aging
projects.project_description:
OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE
Research in the Davis Center is uniquely focused on using diverse animal models to define the cellular and
molecular mechanisms of tissue regeneration and aging, and on translating that information into new
regenerative medicine therapies and improvements to healthspan. This Phase III COBRE proposal will transition
state of the art core facilities at MDIBL in comparative animal models, bioinformatics and data science, and light
microscopy to self-sustainability and support a pilot project program in aging and regenerative biology which will
enable MDIBL investigators, visiting scientists, pilot project awardees, and MDIBL course participants to build
highly competitive research programs. Core support will consolidate the progress made after hiring, promoting,
and retaining successful COBRE investigators in the MDIBL Davis Center and building this Center into a leading
research institute in Comparative Biology.

The MDIBL Center for Comparative Biology of Tissue Repair, Regeneration and Aging

projects.project_title: Comparative Animal Models (CAM) Core
Light Microscopy Facility Core
Comparative Animal Models (CAM) Core

Administrative Core
tRNA Gene Replacement Therapy for tRNA-Synthetase Related Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disorder
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) includes many forms of inherited peripheral neuropathy and affects 1:2500
people. There is no approved treatment for any of the one-hundred genetic subtypes of CMT, representing a
large unmet clinical need. Here we are proposing to optimize a gene therapy approach for CMT type 2D that
will apply to all patients with dominant mutations in the glycyl tRNA synthetase (GARS) gene.

projects.project_title: tRNA Gene Replacement Therapy for tRNA-Synthetase Related Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disorder
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) includes many forms of inherited peripheral neuropathy and affects 1:2500
people. There is no approved treatment for any of the one-hundred genetic subtypes of CMT, representing a
large unmet clinical need. Here we are proposing to optimize a gene therapy approach for CMT type 2D that

projects.project_title: Lrfn2 as a Novel Resilience Factor to Protect Against Alzheimer's Disease-Related Cortical Neurodegeneration
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Currently, over six million Americans are living with Alzheimer's disease (AD), and by 2050 this number is
projected to rise to nearly 13 million if no disease-modifying treatments are discovered. The lack of successful
therapeutic options can be attributed to the complexity of AD and the limited understanding of the genetic and
neuronal mechanisms that underly AD. I performed genetic mapping of brain-composition traits in a panel of
genetically diverse mice that model human AD to identify Lrfn2 as a gene that modifies AD-related cortical
neurodegeneration, and in the proposed project I will determine if Lrfn2 is a genuine mediator of resilience to
AD and is a valid target for development of effective treatments for AD.

projects.project_title: Spatiotemporal control of RGS signaling
projects.project_description:
Narrative
The negative regulation of receptor signaling is important to prevent cancer and heart disease.
We propose to use the yeast pheromone response as a model system for receptor signaling to
understand how localization of the regulator of G-protein signaling (RGS) is changed over time
and how that impacts the cellular response to extracellular signal.

projects.project_title: Lrfn2 as a Novel Resilience Factor to Protect Against Alzheimer's Disease-Related Cortical Neurodegeneration
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Currently, over six million Americans are living with Alzheimer's disease (AD), and by 2050 this number is

projects.project_title: Bruker Single Cell Proteomics Mass Spectrometer System
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Recent advances in biomedical research have demonstrated that analysis of single cells is essential for
understanding the biological processes underlying development and disease. At The Jackson Laboratory
(JAX), we have the capability to analyze diverse components in the pathways involved in protein production,
including RNA and DNA molecules, and other molecules that modify levels of proteins generated from RNA or
DNA, but currently we have no options for high-throughput identification of the “proteome,” i.e., the complete
set of proteins, in a single cell. Access to the Bruker timsTOF SCP mass spectrometer and the accompanying
cellenONE for sample processing requested in this application will provide investigators at both JAX and other
Maine research institutions with access to a state-of-the-art single-cell proteomics system that will significantly
advance research on a broad range of diseases.

projects.project_title: Genomics in Action
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The Jackson Laboratory, in partnership with community college faculty across the state of Connecticut, proposes
to develop a curriculum program to improve genetics and genomics literacy among community college students
preparing to enter the biomedical research workforce. By targeting students training for entry-level professions
and by developing online content modules, we seek to train a broad and diverse audience. Our content modules
will expand students’ understanding of how human genomics intersects with healthcare, ultimately strengthening
the future STEM workforce.

projects.project_title: Genomics in Action
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE

projects.project_title: Skin immunity as a function of frailty, aging, and skin microbiome composition
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Older adults, particularly frail older adults have greatly increased susceptibility to skin disorders and infections.
We will investigate how the skin microbiome modulates skin immunity in healthy and unhealthy aging. This
work will lay the foundation for modulating the microbiome-immune axis for therapeutic or prophylactic
approaches, and identify risk factors for a range of skin disorders in older adults.

projects.project_title: Role of ARMS2 mutations in age-related macular degeneration
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The Chr10q26 locus, containing ARMS2/HTRA1, has been found in large scale human population studies to
contribute to a significant proportion of the risk for developing age-related macular degeneration (AMD), one of
the leading causes of vision impairment and loss in the aging population. Due to strong linkage disequilbrium
between the two genes, it is still unclear which gene (or both) contribute to the increased risk. In this application,
we plan to further determine if the disease phenotypes observed in mice bearing an ARMS2A69S allele might be
due to reduction in the integrity of the outer blood retinal barrier or to mitochondrial dysfunction and determine
whether environmental factors such as consumption of a high fat diet, or genetic factors such as rare human
complement factor H disease alleles exacerbate the disease in ARMS2A69S mice.

projects.project_title: The Role of the Ventromedial Nucleus of the Hypothalamus in Epileptogenesis
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
While current therapeutic approaches for epilepsy primarily focus on symptom management and seizure suppression,
there remains a critical gap in targeting the underlying processes of brain reorganization (epileptogenesis) in individuals
with epilepsy. The primary goals of this study encompass the following objectives: 1) identifying neuroanatomical and
molecular mechanisms by which the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus (VMH) is involved in epileptogenic
processes and 2) determining the genomic landscape of the epileptogenic processes in the VMH using spatial
transcriptomics. By elucidating mechanisms and signaling pathways regulating the reorganizational processes in the VMH
that lead to brainstem-tonic seizures and increased risk for Sudden Unexpected Death in EPilepsy (SUDEP), potential
druggable targets for epilepsy and/or SUDEP can be identified.

projects.project_title: The Role of the Ventromedial Nucleus of the Hypothalamus in Epileptogenesis
projects.project_description:

projects.project_title: The Genetics of the Neuromuscular Junction: Mechanisms and Disease Models
projects.project_description: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease affects approximately 1:2500 people and the largest family of genes associated with this disorder is the tRNA-synthetases. How mutations in these ubiquitous genes lead to the degeneration of specific nerves is unknown. We are exploring the biochemical and cell biological basis of these disorders using mice and human cell lines engineered to model patient mutations; this work will also test both pharmacological and gene therapy treatment strategies.

projects.project_title: The Genetics of the Neuromuscular Junction: Mechanisms and Disease Models
projects.project_description: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease affects approximately 1:2500 people and the largest family of genes associated with this disorder is the tRNA-synthetases. How mutations in these ubiquitous genes lead to the degeneration of specific nerves is unknown. We are exploring the biochemical and cell biological basis of these disorders using mice and human cell lines engineered to model patient mutations; this work will also test both pharmacological and gene therapy treatment strategies.

projects.project_title: Molecular mechanisms of staphylococcal modulation of skin homeostasis
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Staphylococcus sp. are essential members of the human skin microbiome. We seek to understand the
mechanisms by which genetically diverse staphylococci isolated from human skin contribute to skin health and
homeostasis.

projects.project_title: Role of ARMS2 mutations in age-related macular degeneration
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The Chr10q26 locus, containing ARMS2/HTRA1, has been found in large scale human population studies to
contribute to a significant proportion of the risk for developing age-related macular degeneration (AMD), one of
the leading causes of vision impairment and loss in the aging population. Due to strong linkage disequilbrium
between the two genes, it is still unclear which gene (or both) contribute to the increased risk. In this application,
we plan to further determine if the disease phenotypes observed in mice bearing an ARMS2A69S allele might be

projects.project_title: Foundational Training in the Use of the Laboratory Mouse as a Model of Human Disease
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The laboratory mouse is the best genetically defined experimental vertebrate model organism for humans and,
with widespread use in biomedical research, continues to present a major opportunity for advancement in the
understanding of the genetics, biology and interventions of human disease. While many institutions provide
ample access to didactic courses, few, if any, have intensive hands-on training in the experimental use of the
laboratory mouse. Therefore, we propose to provide a unique opportunity to the next generation of biomedical
researchers and health care providers by adapting a highly successful and high-impact workshop that we have
thus far offered at The Jackson Laboratory and taking it “on the road” to their home institutions with an explicit
focus on reducing barriers to participation by diverse and disadvantaged learner groups.

projects.project_title: Foundational Training in the Use of the Laboratory Mouse as a Model of Human Disease
projects.project_description:

projects.project_title: Assessing molecular predictors of triple negative breast cancer therapeutic response in Black, White, and Hispanic patients in a community healthcare system
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive breast cancer subtype with higher incidence and worse
clinical outcomes for non-Hispanic Black (NHB) and Hispanic women compared to non-Hispanic White women
(NHW), even when risks are adjusted for clinical and socio-economic factors. We recently identified four TNBC
subtypes robustly prognostic for therapy response based on BRCA1/2 gene status and the level of expression
of an immune-related gene signature. Here, we propose to determine the prevalence of these distinct molecular
subtypes in NHW, NHB, and Hispanic TNBC patients to assess whether they disproportionally occur in specific
racial/ethnic groups and may therefore contribute to the observed disparities in therapy response outcomes.

projects.project_title: Assessing molecular predictors of triple negative breast cancer therapeutic response in Black, White, and Hispanic patients in a community healthcare system
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE

projects.project_title: Protective adaptive immune mechanisms after cardiac arrest
projects.project_description:
Public Health Relevance Statement:
Sudden cardiac arrest is a major public health issue in the United States. The purpose of this study is to
determine the role of CD73 expressing lymphocytes in the protection against excessive inflammation and
secondary heart and brain tissue damage after initial global ischemia and reperfusion injury. The anticipated
data may lead to the development of novel immunotherapies to cure patients with cardiac arrest.

projects.project_title: Protective adaptive immune mechanisms after cardiac arrest
projects.project_description:
Public Health Relevance Statement:
Sudden cardiac arrest is a major public health issue in the United States. The purpose of this study is to
determine the role of CD73 expressing lymphocytes in the protection against excessive inflammation and

data may lead to the development of novel immunotherapies to cure patients with cardiac arrest.

projects.project_title: Implementation of Innovative Treatment for Moral Injury Syndrome: A Hybrid Type 2 Study
projects.project_description:
Moral Injury Syndrome (MIS) affects up to 35-60% of Veterans managing combat-related PTSD;
it results from experiences that challenge deeply held values or spiritual beliefs. Symptoms of
MIS may include hopelessness, helplessness, loss of spiritual beliefs, difficulty with forgiveness,
loss of meaning or purpose, reduced trust in self or others, or intractable guilt, shame or anger.
Veterans managing MIS have difficulty responding to mental health treatment, and are at
increased risk for suicide ideation or attempts. To date evidence-based interventions for MIS are
not widely available in VA. This study will implement an evidence-based intervention for MIS in
four VA facilities, collect data on the effectiveness of the intervention, and develop an
implementation toolkit. This data will inform national dissemination in collaboration with the
Office of Mental Health and Suicide Prevention and the National Chaplain Service.

projects.project_title: Summer Research Experience in Neurobiology at The Jackson Laboratory
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
A trained and diverse biomedical workforce requires support of educational programs at all levels, including those
designed to provide students exposure to biomedical research, reinforce their intent to graduate with a science
degree, and to prepare them for graduate studies leading to a career in research. The proposed summer
research program will provide opportunities for students to improve their research skills and gain confidence in
the research environment.

projects.project_title: Modeling Hearing and Balance Disorders in Mice: the HEar@JAX Workshop
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The “Modeling Hearing and Balance Disorders in Mice: The HEar@JAX Workshop” highlights the unique strengths
of the laboratory mouse as a model to study human auditory and vestibular function in health and disease. Animal
models are critical to the development of effective new therapeutic approaches for treating hearing loss and
balance disorders. Explaining and demonstrating how mice can be used for that goal is also important for the
correct public perception of animal research.

projects.project_title: Long-term risk for psychiatric disorders following early life exposure to environmental arsenic
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Environmental arsenic is a major public health concern, and early life exposure to arsenic from well water or food
increases adult risk of developing of psychiatric disorders such as depression and anxiety in adulthood, by
unknown mechanisms. This project will test the hypothesis that early life exposure to arsenic increases risk of
developing psychiatric disorders by perturbing developmental gene expression in the brain, resulting in persistent
glucocorticoid resistance and impeded regulation of neuroinflammation and stress responsivity across the
lifespan.

projects.project_title: Long-term risk for psychiatric disorders following early life exposure to environmental arsenic
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Environmental arsenic is a major public health concern, and early life exposure to arsenic from well water or food
increases adult risk of developing of psychiatric disorders such as depression and anxiety in adulthood, by
unknown mechanisms. This project will test the hypothesis that early life exposure to arsenic increases risk of
developing psychiatric disorders by perturbing developmental gene expression in the brain, resulting in persistent
glucocorticoid resistance and impeded regulation of neuroinflammation and stress responsivity across the
lifespan.

projects.project_title: Mitochondrial function regulates ROS-mediated patterning following injury
projects.project_description:
Narrative
Mitochondria are essential for cell survival not only as sources of ATP but also as factors that control intracellular
signaling. The role of mitochondrial generated ROS and signaling in regulating bone regeneration is currently
unknown. This proposal seeks to identify the role of two novel mitochondrial related factors BNIP3 and NIX in
regulating digit regeneration to elucidate mechanisms that can be targeted to enhance bone regeneration.

projects.project_title: Mitochondrial function regulates ROS-mediated patterning following injury
projects.project_description:
Narrative
Mitochondria are essential for cell survival not only as sources of ATP but also as factors that control intracellular
signaling. The role of mitochondrial generated ROS and signaling in regulating bone regeneration is currently
unknown. This proposal seeks to identify the role of two novel mitochondrial related factors BNIP3 and NIX in
regulating digit regeneration to elucidate mechanisms that can be targeted to enhance bone regeneration.

projects.project_title: Investigating miRNA-Mediated Bone Loss from Morphine Treatment
projects.project_description:
NARRATIVE
Opioids pose a serious risk to skeletal health by compounding bone loss in patients requiring pain
management, such as those with osteoporosis, as well as predispose opioid users to fracture. Preclinical
studies addressing potential causes of reduced bone quality are lacking, and this will be the first proposal to
delineate the role of sensory neuron-osteoblast communication via noncoding microRNAs on opioid-induced
bone loss. Results will provide basic insights on the regulation of bone formation by micro RNAs that may
inform clinical strategies to treat skeletal pain and monitor patients on opioids.

projects.project_title: Investigating miRNA-Mediated Bone Loss from Morphine Treatment
projects.project_description:
NARRATIVE

projects.project_title: Developing Universal Psychosis Screens for Use With Maine Youth in Primary Care
PATHOLOGY MONITORING OF AGED RODENT COLONIES
Molecular mechanisms of staphylococcal modulation of skin homeostasis
projects.project_description:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Staphylococcus sp. are essential members of the human skin microbiome. We seek to understand the
mechanisms by which genetically diverse staphylococci isolated from human skin contribute to skin health and
homeostasis.

projects.project_title: Strategies to Improve Well-Being and Diabetes Management
UNE Center for Cell Signaling Research
projects.project_description:
Dysfunction in cell signaling is a fundamental driver of human disease, and our ability to
optimize healthy, pain-free aging and find new treatments for neurodegenerative and metabolic
diseases requires a broad understanding of the way cells communicate. The Center for Cell
Signaling Research will build critical research infrastructure and support the research programs
of junior investigators to meet these contemporary clinical challenges.

projects.project_title: The function of germ granule processes that maintain pluripotency in the C. elegans germline
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
Cellular pluripotency in the germline is maintained through processes within cytoplasmic assemblies called germ
granules. The parent grant seeks to understand the function of individual germ-granule proteins, the purpose
and conditions of their assembly, and their capacity for cellular reprogramming. This administrative supplement
replaces an aging ultralow temperature freezer that is used to house the live strains and reagents needed for
the studies outlined in the parent grant.

projects.project_title: Project 4 - Queme
The function of germ granule processes that maintain pluripotency in the C. elegans germline
projects.project_description:
Project Narrative
Cellular pluripotency in the germline is maintained through processes within cytoplasmic assemblies called germ
granules. Core germ-granule proteins are conserved in almost all animals, frequently repurposed during
development, and re-expressed in multi-potent cancers. Understanding the function of individual germ-granule
proteins, the purpose and conditions of their assembly, and their capacity for cellular reprogramming, will lead
to applications that improve reproductive health, regeneration, and cancer therapeutics.

projects.project_title: Sweet Blood: Diabetes and the Changing Nature of Modern Health
projects.project_description:
The proposed research project is relevant to public health because it is the first book-length
interdisciplinary historical study of the environmental origins and consequences of a major chronic illness.
Sweet Blood: Diabetes and the Changing Nature of Modern Health will benefit biomedical scientists,
clinicians, historians of medicine, and public health experts by shedding new light on the deep historical
antecedents to current social determinants of health. The project is germane to the Public Health Service
because it explains how shifting relationships with mutable ecologies create or reinforce inequalities
between individuals and populations, further driving diabetes prevalence alongside socioeconomic
disparities.
